comments.author: Juno
comments.content: A lovely recipe and a stunning photograph. I'm not a vegetarian, but my mouth is watering at the thought of this dish. Thank you!  Juno (South Africa).

comments.author: Tofu Hunter
comments.content: Ha, yes, Hippie Food. I always struggle to categorize this (wonderful) particular genre as well. Looks delicious.

comments.author: Alana
comments.content:
I lived for two years in a vegetarian consensus-run cooperative house that by anyone's account was thoroughly hippie. And yes, I agree, that's hippie food. Also in that genre: a random stir-fry of veggies and spices served over a random grain, assuming the lack of cultural similarity still holds. Amazing how hearty and delicious that can be.

My only quibble would be that I've never rinsed my quinoa before cooking. Seems like too much extra work for no reason; the quinoa never tastes bitter at all. Not worth it, in my opinion.

comments.author: Ivy Manning
comments.content: Tree-hugger! Ha! I don't think the people of the Andes think of themselves as hippies and they eat quinoa as a staple. Have you ever tried the red quinoa? Is there a taste difference?

comments.author: Alessandra
comments.content: Mmmh, I really must try to use more quinoa. Thank you for the recipe Michael!

comments.author: Jennifer
comments.content: Such a great combo! I love quinoa!! Im going to have to try this!!!

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Alana - sounds like we lived in the same co-op :). I think the deal with the quinoa is that some producers pre-rinse and others don't, at least that is what I gather from Wikipedia. So depending on what you've got, it might not be necessary. I find it only take a minute - I certainly don't do any multi-hour soak like some people say.

comments.author: Tofu Mom
comments.content: YAY for Hippie Food! THIS IS TOTALLY something I'd eat!!

comments.author: Kate Frank
comments.content: I never thought of using tahini with quinoa. What a great idea!

comments.author: Daily Spud
comments.content: I definitely find that quinoa and sesame work well together - one of my standby lunches is quinoa + toasted sesame oil + soy sauce + lemon juice + whatever crunchy veg come to hand...

comments.author: Janice
comments.content:
I love most any dish that thinks to add tofu to it's ranks.
Smart. and delicious.

comments.author: samantha
comments.content:
I cooked this tonight for dinner and it was delicious! I substituted gold potatoes (boiled) for tofu and sauteed the green beans in olive oil with salt + pepper. Between the salt in the tahini mixture and my addition, I found I overdid it. I probably added almost a cup of water to the tahini mixture to get the right consistency, but make sure you add it small increments. I also used three garlic cloves instead of one, and found that it could've used more lemon (I only had a small one on hand). I garnished with aleppo. 

enjoy! and thank you, Michael!
